study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating phosphatidylserine (PS) into non-viral lipid nanoparticle (LNP) constructs could enhance cellular transfection efficiency for gene delivery.
results_summary: The study found that PS-decorated LNPs significantly improved nucleic acid delivery, with a 6-fold increase in transgene expression in vitro and a 5.2-fold enhancement in vivo for mRNA-LNPs, while pDNA-LNPs showed a 3.2-fold increase. Optimal PS concentrations were identified as 2.5 to 5% of total lipids.
population_specificity: Cultured HuH-7 hepatocellular carcinoma cells (in vitro) and unspecified in vivo models.
effective_dosage: 2.5 to 5% of total lipids in LNPs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize Phosphatidylserine (PS) formulation for stability and bioavailability and investigate its neuroprotective effects, particularly on learning, memory, and myelination in mice.
results_summary: The study found that 2% (w/w) PS emulsion improved spatial learning and memory in mice, upregulated key neuroprotective proteins (BDNF, TrkB, PSD95, mTOR, MBP, ErbB4), and enhanced myelination via Nrg-1/ErbB4 signaling. PS also improved emulsion stability with smaller particle size, higher ζ-potential, and lower surface tension.
population_specificity: 5- and 12-week-old mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of itraconazole on membrane-associated lipids, including phosphatidylserine, in cervical cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that itraconazole treatment significantly decreased phosphatidylserine levels and increased lysophosphatidylcholine levels in CaSki cells, suggesting alterations in phospholipid composition. These changes may contribute to the anticancer activity of itraconazole.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer CaSki cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TCR activation-driven phosphatidylserine (PS) exposure on CD8 T cells could be exploited to deliver interleukin-2 (IL-2) via an annexin V-IL2 fusion protein (AnnV-IL2) to enhance T cell activation and immunity.
results_summary: AnnV-IL2 specifically bound PS on TCR-stimulated CD8 T cells, significantly enhancing T cell activation compared to recombinant IL-2. In vivo, AnnV-IL2 promoted robust expansion of antigen-specific T cells and stronger secondary responses upon rechallenge.
population_specificity: CD8 T cells in vitro and in mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether RGD peptide-presenting phosphatidylserine liposomes (RGD-PSLs) could enhance macrophage immunomodulation and bone tissue regeneration in a rat calvarial defect model.
results_summary: RGD-PSLs, particularly at 3% RGD concentration, improved macrophage phagocytosis, suppressed proinflammatory cytokine expression, promoted M2 polarization, and accelerated new bone formation compared to PSLs alone.
population_specificity: Rat calvarial defect model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the presence of anti-phosphatidylserine/prothrombin (aPS/PT) antibodies in patients with Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) and their correlation with clinical manifestations.
results_summary: The study found that aPS/PT antibodies were infrequent in patients with longstanding inactive PAN, with only one PAN patient testing positive for aPS/PT IgG. Lupus anticoagulant (LA) was the most commonly identified antibody.
population_specificity: Patients with PAN (n=14), Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA, n=10), and Behçet's disease (BD, n=10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a near-infrared fluorescent probe (1-DPA2) targeting phosphatidylserine (PS) and active caspase-3 for early detection and monitoring of acute kidney injury (AKI) in mice.
results_summary: The study found that 1-DPA2 effectively targeted PS and active caspase-3, enabling early detection of cisplatin-induced AKI in mice at 24 hours post-treatment and allowed longitudinal monitoring of kidney function recovery following therapy.
population_specificity: Mice with cisplatin-induced acute kidney injury.
study_duration: Monitoring occurred as early as 24 hours post-cisplatin treatment, with follow-up during recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of phosphatidylserine (PtdSer) transport mechanisms in KRAS PM localization and oncogenesis, and whether targeting these mechanisms could inhibit KRAS-dependent tumor growth.
results_summary: The study found that ORP5 and ORP8, PtdSer transport proteins, are essential for KRAS PM localization and oncogenesis. Targeting PI4KIIIα with simeprevir disrupted KRAS PM localization and inhibited tumor growth, especially when combined with MAPK and PI3K inhibitors.
population_specificity: KRAS-mutant pancreatic cancer cell lines and mouse models, with analysis of human pancreatic tumor datasets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of autoimmunity against Phosphatidylserine (PS) in anemia during Trypanosoma brucei infection in mice and humans.
results_summary: The study found that T. brucei infection leads to increased anti-PS antibodies and atypical B-cell expansion, contributing to anemia. Treatment with Annexin V, which prevents PS binding, improved anemia in infected mice, and high anti-PS antibody levels correlated with anemia in human patients.
population_specificity: Mouse models (T. brucei and T. cruzi) and human patients with human African trypanosomiasis (HAT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of phosphatidylserine-capped gold nanoparticles (PS-AuNPs) in breast and prostate cancer cells in vitro.
results_summary: PS-AuNPs induced apoptosis in both breast and prostate cancer cells, evidenced by changes in cell morphology and significant increases in DNA fragmentation compared to controls. The findings suggest PS-AuNPs could be a potential treatment for these cancers.
population_specificity: Breast and prostate cancer cell lines (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop multifunctional liposomes containing phosphatidylserine (PS) to enhance drug delivery and neuroprotection in Parkinson's disease (PD) models.
results_summary: The study found that PS-containing liposomes improved blood-brain barrier penetration, reduced α-synuclein and phosphorylated tau protein levels, and enhanced neuroprotective effects by modulating Bax, Bcl-2, tyrosine hydroxylase, and dopamine transporter expressions.
population_specificity: MPP+-insulted SH-SY5Y cells (a Parkinson's disease cell model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Phosphatidylserine (PS) in tumor immunotherapy, focusing on its immunosuppressive effects in the tumor microenvironment and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that PS exposure in the tumor microenvironment suppresses anti-tumor immunity, promoting tumor growth and metastasis. PS-targeted therapy shows promise in inhibiting tumor growth and enhancing the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors.
population_specificity: Not specified (general tumor microenvironment context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of SapC-DOPS, a nanosome targeting phosphatidylserine, for selectively treating pancreatic cancer and metastases.
results_summary: SapC-DOPS demonstrated selective targeting of pancreatic tumors and metastases with an impressive safety profile, showing only minor side effects in preclinical and phase I clinical trials. The treatment showed promise as a potential addition to current pancreatic cancer therapies.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer patients (preclinical and phase I clinical trial participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phosphatidylserine (PS) released by dead mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) contributes to their immunomodulatory therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that PS released by apoptotic MSCs or administered as PS liposomes (PSLs) mimicked the protective effects of live MSCs in multiple injury models, with MerTK and CCR2 identified as key mediators of this effect.
population_specificity: Mouse models (acute liver injury, lung injury, spinal cord injury)
effective_dosage: Not specified (study used 5 × 10⁴ dead MSCs or equivalent PS liposomes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ExoBlock, a novel PS-binding molecule, could reverse exosome-mediated immunosuppression in the tumor microenvironment and enhance T-cell responses.
results_summary: ExoBlock effectively bound PS and blocked immunosuppressive activity of tumor-associated exosomes in vitro. In vivo, it enhanced T-cell-mediated tumor suppression, reduced tumor burden and metastasis, and decreased circulating PS+ exosomes in tumor-bearing mice.
population_specificity: Human tumor xenograft models (melanoma-based X-mouse and ovarian tumor-based OTX models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of two PS-targeting monoclonal antibodies (11.31 and bavituximab) on TCR activation and cytokine production in activated human T cells.
results_summary: The study found that 11.31, but not bavituximab, suppressed cytokine production (IFN-γ and TNF-ɑ) in anti-CD3/CD28 activated T cells, suggesting distinct functional activities of these PS-targeting mAbs. The inhibitory effect was directly mediated by binding to externalized PS on activated T cells, independent of monocytes.
population_specificity: Human T cells from healthy donor PBMCs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of phosphatidylserine (PS) in chemotherapy-induced microparticles and their effects on coagulation and metastasis in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: The study found that PS+ breast cancer cell-derived microparticles (BCMPs) increased procoagulant activity and promoted metastasis, but lactadherin treatment reduced these effects by blocking PS-mediated interactions.
population_specificity: 20 healthy individuals and 18 recently diagnosed TNBC patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the ameliorating effects of DHA-enriched phosphatidylserine (DHA-PS) on high-fat diet-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a mouse model.
results_summary: DHA-PS treatment improved NAFLD, reduced serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and inflammatory markers, increased beneficial gut microbiota diversity, and enhanced liver function.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet to induce NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phosphatidylserine (PS) externalization on colonic capillaries could be targeted by Annexin A5 (ANXA5) for therapeutic effects in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that ANXA5, which binds to externalized PS, effectively targeted the colon and alleviated experimental colitis by inhibiting endothelial cell activation and reducing inflammatory cell infiltration. ANXA5's PS-binding ability was crucial for its therapeutic effects, as a mutant lacking this ability showed no efficacy.
population_specificity: Experimental colitis model (not specified if human or animal, but HUVECs were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining DPX-R9F with anti-phosphatidylserine (PS) and/or anti-PD-1 antibodies enhances anti-tumor immune responses in a mouse model of HPV16 E7-expressing tumors.
results_summary: The combination of DPX-R9F and anti-PS antibodies, with or without anti-PD-1, increased efficacy compared to untreated controls, activating T cells and elevating cytotoxic T cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells in the tumor microenvironment.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice implanted with HPV16 E7-expressing C3 tumors.

study_goal: To investigate whether phosphatidylserine liposomes (PSL) can protect against post-stroke neuroinflammation and depression in mice.
results_summary: PSL reduced immobility time in behavioral tests (indicating antidepressant effects), increased viable neuron counts, and lowered inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α and IL-10) in the hippocampus of stroke-induced mice.
population_specificity: Stroke-induced mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Phosphatidylserine (PS) in promoting a prothrombotic state in patients with periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that PS-positive cells and microvesicles were elevated in severe periodontitis, contributing to increased clotting and prothrombinase complex formation. Non-surgical periodontal therapy reduced PS exposure and microvesicle release.
population_specificity: 138 patients with periodontitis and 42 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence of thromboembolic events (TEs) in SLE patients positive for anti-phosphatidylserine/prothrombin (aPS/PT) antibodies, focusing on their risk compared to aPS/PT-negative patients.
results_summary: The study found that aPS/PT-positive SLE patients had a higher cumulative incidence of TEs (16.7%) compared to the overall cohort (5.8% after 2 years). IgG aPS/PT positivity was significantly associated with increased TE risk (HR 19.6).
population_specificity: 52 SLE patients (80.8% women) with no prior TEs, no anti-thrombotic therapy, and isolated aPS/PT positivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of phosphatidylserine for reducing ADHD symptoms, particularly inattention, in children.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed a statistically significant effect of phosphatidylserine (200-300 mg/day) on inattention symptoms but no significant effects on overall ADHD symptoms or hyperactivity-impulsivity. The evidence quality was low, warranting further research.
population_specificity: Children aged ≤18 years diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether blocking Phosphatidylserine (PS) interactions could enhance the anti-tumor effects of radiation therapy (RT) and PD-1 pathway blockade in melanoma.
results_summary: The study found that PS expression increased on immune cells after RT, and blocking PS with an antibody (mch1N11) improved RT's anti-tumor efficacy and survival. Combining anti-PD-1 with RT and mch1N11 further enhanced these effects.
population_specificity: Mouse B16 melanoma models and patients with metastatic melanoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether serum levels of ATX and PS-PLA1 (related to phosphatidylserine metabolism) are associated with pathological and clinical findings in lupus nephritis (LN) compared to other glomerular diseases.
results_summary: Serum levels of ATX and PS-PLA1 were higher in LN patients than in those with other glomerular diseases. Lower ATX levels correlated with higher disease activity and chronicity indices, possibly due to treatment effects, but did not reflect proteinuria or kidney survival.
population_specificity: 39 patients with lupus nephritis and 37 patients with other glomerular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of phosphatidylserine (PS) exposure in endothelial dysfunction and thrombosis in T2D patients with COVID-19, including long COVID.
results_summary: The study found that PS exposure on endothelial cells promotes thrombosis in T2D patients with COVID-19, contributing to hypercoagulability. It also highlighted the importance of early antithrombotic therapy to improve outcomes.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) patients with COVID-19, including those with long COVID.
interactions: Potential interactions between antidiabetic, anticoagulant, and antiviral drugs were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between anti-Phosphatidylserine/Prothrombin antibodies (aPS/PT) and recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and assess the effectiveness of treatment in aPS/PT-positive patients.
results_summary: The study found that aPS/PT antibodies were significantly associated with RPL, with odds ratios ranging from 5.96 to 7.28 across different RPL groups. Treatment with heparin, aspirin, and/or hydroxychloroquine resulted in successful live births in all aPS/PT-positive pregnant patients.
population_specificity: Healthy women with unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), categorized into Extra-Criteria (EC), Early Miscarriage (EM), and Fetal Loss (FL) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of Phosphatidylserine in coagulation pathways, particularly under septic conditions and endothelial cell injury.
results_summary: The study found that Phosphatidylserine is externalized on injured endothelial cells, serving as a scaffold for coagulation factors, which contributes to aberrant coagulation activation. Hemodilution exacerbates this effect, but recombinant antithrombin and thrombomodulin can partially suppress it.
population_specificity: Endothelial cells under septic/injured conditions (in vitro focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm whether Lipogen's phosphatidylserine (PS) and phosphatidic acid (PA) complex (PAS) alleviates premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms in a controlled clinical trial setting.
results_summary: PAS significantly improved PMS symptoms (DRSP Total score) compared to placebo, with notable improvements in physical and depressive symptoms. Salivary and serum cortisol levels also showed favorable changes in the PAS group, though other biomarkers and PMS/PMDD criteria reduction did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-45 years with a diagnosis of PMS.
effective_dosage: 400 mg PS and 400 mg PA per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the absorption, safety, and cognitive effects of a phosphatidylserine (PS) and phosphatidic acid (PA) supplement in healthy volunteers, elderly individuals with memory problems, and Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that PS was efficiently absorbed, improved memory and mood in elderly subjects, and stabilized daily functioning and emotional state in AD patients, with no reported negative side effects.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers, elderly individuals with memory problems, and patients with Alzheimer's disease.
effective_dosage: 300 mg PS + 240 mg PA per day (three capsules).
study_duration: 3 months for elderly subjects, 2 months for AD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize cell wall lipids, including phosphatidylserine, in P. brasiliensis isolates grown with and without human plasma to understand their role in fungal biology and host interaction.
results_summary: The study detected phosphatidylserine among other phospholipids in P. brasiliensis cell walls, with differences in lipid profiles between isolates and plasma supplementation, but did not assess its effects on humans.
population_specificity: Fungal isolates (P. brasiliensis Pb3 and Pb18)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sperm selection by density gradient centrifugation before cryopreservation and hypotaurine supplementation could improve post-thaw sperm quality in infertile men with oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, focusing on markers like phosphatidylserine externalization.
results_summary: The study found that sperm selection before freezing improved recovery rates and reduced markers of apoptosis, including phosphatidylserine externalization. Hypotaurine supplementation further reduced PS externalization in live sperm when selection was performed before freezing.
population_specificity: 64 infertile men with oligoasthenoteratozoospermia undergoing evaluation at a reproductive medicine center.
study_duration: Not specified (study conducted between January 2009 and June 2010)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy-derived phosphatidylserine (PS) supplementation improves ADHD symptoms and cognitive performance in children.
results_summary: PS supplementation significantly improved ADHD symptoms, short-term auditory memory, and reduced inattention and impulsivity, with no adverse effects reported. No significant improvements were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-14 years with ADHD who had not previously received drug treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 phosphatidylserine (PS) supplementation reduces chronic and acute stress in healthy men.
results_summary: Omega-3 PS showed no significant overall effect on stress measures but reduced stress in highly chronically stressed individuals and restored cortisol responses in low responders.
population_specificity: 60 healthy nonsmoking men aged 30 to 60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of phosphatidylserine and phosphatidylserine/phosphatidic acid complex (PAS) supplementation on the endocrine stress response in chronically stressed subjects.
results_summary: PAS 400 (400 mg PS & 400 mg PA daily) normalized ACTH, salivary, and serum cortisol responses to acute stress in highly stressed subjects, while PAS 200 showed no significant effects. No significant effects were observed on heart rate, pulse transit time, or psychological stress response.
population_specificity: 75 healthy male volunteers stratified by chronic stress levels (high vs. low).
effective_dosage: 400 mg PS & 400 mg PA (PAS 400) or 200 mg PS & 200 mg PA (PAS 200) per day.

study_goal: The researchers sought to understand the mechanism behind the occurrence of two peaks in the thrombin generation curve in platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and the role of phosphatidylserine (PS) in this process.
results_summary: The study found that delayed phosphatidylserine (PS) exposure on platelets, caused by certain antagonists (MeS-AMP, PGE1, DMSO), leads to a second peak in thrombin generation. Increasing platelet concentration or combining DMSO with PGE1 eliminated the second peak and reduced the first peak's amplitude.
population_specificity: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and platelet-poor plasma (PPP) in vitro models.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (in vitro study with specific concentrations: 160 µM MeS-AMP, 83 nM PGE1, 1.6% DMSO).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of safe-sourced PS-omega-3 in improving memory abilities in elderly individuals with subjective memory complaints.
results_summary: PS-omega-3 supplementation resulted in a 42% increase in delayed word recall ability, suggesting a favorable effect on memory. The study concluded that PS-omega-3 may serve as a safe alternative to bovine-derived phosphatidylserine.
population_specificity: Elderly volunteers with subjective memory complaints (n=8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how nitrate recycle ratios affect the distribution and abundance of denitrifying and non-denitrifying polyphosphate-accumulating organisms (DPAOs and non-DPAOs) in an IFAS-EBPR system for phosphorus removal.
results_summary: The study found that DPAO populations correlated positively with nitrate recycle flows, while non-DPAOs showed negative correlation. DPAOs contributed less than 10% to overall denitrification, and optimizing nitrate recycle ratios (around 1.5) enhanced DPAO performance in wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Lab-scale continuous-flow IFAS-EBPR system (microbial populations, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Nitrate recycle ratios of 1.0, 1.5, and 2.5Q were tested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel wastewater treatment process for efficient nitrogen and phosphorus removal using micron zeolite powder carriers and hydrocyclone separators.
results_summary: The study achieved high nitrogen (85.2%) and phosphorus (78.9%) removal efficiencies, outperforming conventional systems, with enhanced microbial cooperation and functional gene upregulation.
population_specificity: Municipal wastewater treatment systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of inoculating Acinetobacter indicus CZH-5 in enhancing nitrogen, phosphorus, and tetracycline removal in swine wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Inoculation with CZH-5 significantly improved removal efficiencies of total nitrogen (92.8%), total phosphate (88.4%), and tetracycline (93.1%), outperforming the control by 26%-71%. The process involved complete nitrification-denitrification for nitrogen and transformation of accumulated phosphorus into phosphate monoesters within the biofilm.
population_specificity: Swine wastewater treatment systems

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize different forms of phosphorus (P) in surface water particulates entering and leaving constructed wetlands to improve long-term phosphorus removal performance.
results_summary: The study found that orthophosphate was the most abundant P component at inflows (~36%), while outflow waters contained significant polyphosphates (up to 39%) and hydroxyapatite, suggesting internal transformation processes within the wetland. The findings indicate that outflow particulate P may be largely biogenic and inorganic P may be apatitic.
population_specificity: Surface water particulates in constructed wetlands (Everglades Stormwater Treatment Areas).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of homeopathic Phosphorus (6C, 30C, and 200C) on normal and immunosuppressed mice.
results_summary: Phosphorus 6C significantly increased humoral immune responses, while 30C and 200C enhanced phagocytic activity and raised TNF-α and IL-2 levels in immunosuppressed mice. No significant changes were observed in hematological or organ index parameters.
population_specificity: Mice (normal and cyclophosphamide-induced immunosuppressed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of ecological restoration versus rehabilitation in improving phosphorus cycling, plant diversity, and soil microbial diversity in degraded ecosystems.
results_summary: Ecological restoration outperformed rehabilitation in grassland and forest ecosystems, showing higher belowground biomass, plant diversity, and microbial diversity, as well as more stable long-term phosphorus cycling. Rehabilitation was less efficient and stable for phosphorus cycling compared to restoration.
population_specificity: Grassland and forest ecosystems (degraded environments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of unbalanced nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) deposition on growth and defense traits in dioecious Populus cathayana.
results_summary: The study found that lower-nitrogen and higher-phosphorus (LNHP) deposition significantly increased biomass accumulation, particularly in females (112% increase). Males showed greater sensitivity to defense substance responses, while females allocated more biomass to leaf development. Both sexes exhibited reduced concentrations of defense substances with increasing N and P deposition.
population_specificity: Dioecious Populus cathayana (a species of poplar tree).
effective_dosage: Gradient N and P deposition (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of phosphorus-solubilizing fungi on the biomass, alkaloid content, and soil environment of Fritillaria taipaiensis.
results_summary: Inoculation with phosphorus-solubilizing fungi significantly increased biomass (up to 62.85%) and alkaloid content (up to 83.87%), while improving soil nutrient levels (e.g., available phosphorus increased by 47.71%). The Z123 group (combination of all three fungi) showed the best overall results.
population_specificity: Fritillaria taipaiensis plants in a controlled pot experiment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (inoculation treatments described but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of gestational exposure to black phosphorus nanoparticles (BPNPs) on fetal growth and placental development in a mouse model and trophoblast cells.
results_summary: BPNPs exposure restricted fetal growth, hindered placental development, and induced trophoblast dysfunction via ROS-regulated, PINK1/Parkin-dependent mitophagy. Mitophagy inhibition (using mdivi-1) mitigated these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice and HTR8/SVneo trophoblast cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent effects observed in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of acid rain on phosphorus (P) status in different plant life-forms (trees and herbs) in a tropical forest.
results_summary: Acid rain reduced inorganic P in tree rhizosphere soil and both inorganic and organic P in herb rhizosphere soil. Trees maintained stable P status, while herbs showed declining leaf and litter P levels, partially compensating via biological mineralization of soil organic P.
population_specificity: Two tree and two herb species in a tropical forest in Southern China.
effective_dosage: Three pH levels (4.0, 3.5, and 3.0) of acid treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate phosphorus recovery from sewage sludge digestate using hydrothermal treatment to optimize its use as a sustainable fertilizer.
results_summary: The study found that temperature and time significantly influenced phosphorus speciation and recovery, with 250-300°C promoting organic phosphorus mineralization and 350°C enhancing phosphorus recovery in solid pellets as calcium phosphates. Hydrothermally treated pellets showed potential as slow-release fertilizers.
population_specificity: Sewage sludge digestate from a wastewater treatment plant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate nutrient management performances, focusing on phosphorus (P) transport, use, and handling between farms and urban environments in the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
results_summary: The study found a sizable increase in potential P losses beyond crop fields, surpassing cropland losses in over 90% of counties. Recovering and recycling P from waste streams could theoretically offset mineral fertilizer inputs in over 60% of counties, but an imbalance in excess N versus P poses risks to aquatic ecosystems.
population_specificity: Chesapeake Bay watershed (county-level data from 1985-2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding silicon to phosphorus fertilization could improve phosphorus availability and uptake in dry-cultivated rice (DCR).
results_summary: Adding silicon to low phosphorus (25P) increased Olsen-P content, root and leaf phosphorus uptake, and enhanced organic acid production and microbial activity, achieving comparable results to higher phosphorus (75P) treatments. Silicon also optimized root-to-shoot ratio and upregulated phosphorus transporters (OsPT2, OsPT4, OsPT8), improving phosphorus conversion and uptake.
population_specificity: Dry-cultivated rice (DCR) in field soil conditions.
effective_dosage: Phosphorus levels: 0, 25, 75 kg·ha⁻¹ P₂O₅; Silicon levels: 0, 45 kg·ha⁻¹ SiO₂.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of black phosphorus nanosheets loaded with magnesium ions and polydopamine (PBP@Mg) in mitigating oxidative stress and inflammation in ischemic stroke.
results_summary: PBP@Mg effectively scavenged reactive oxygen species (ROS), reduced neuronal apoptosis, suppressed inflammation by modulating microglia, and improved neurofunctional behavior in a rat model of ischemic stroke.
population_specificity: Rat model of ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how phosphorus-loaded magnetic biochar (PMLB) affects cadmium (Cd) fraction distribution in rice rhizosphere and its immobilization mechanisms in paddy soils.
results_summary: PMLB application increased soil pH, available phosphorus, and microbial biomass while reducing acetic acid-extractable Cd content in soil and Cd content in brown rice by up to 47.86%. Soil pH, available phosphorus, and urease activity were key drivers of Cd reduction.
population_specificity: Paddy soils and rice plants.
study_duration: Tillering, filling, and maturity periods (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nanovaccine combining photothermal therapy and immunotherapy using black phosphorus (BP) as a nanoplatform for tumor treatment.
results_summary: The BP-PEG-MAL@antigen nanovaccine demonstrated strong stability, biocompatibility, and induced potent immune responses in vitro and in vivo, effectively inhibiting tumor growth, prolonging survival, and preventing recurrence.
population_specificity: Mice with orthotopic and bilateral tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the ability of a traditional maize population and a modern hybrid to utilize organic phosphorus (phytic acid) versus inorganic phosphate for growth.
results_summary: Both maize populations could grow using phytic acid as the sole P source, though less efficiently than inorganic phosphate. Root-released phytase activity and differential gene expression patterns were observed, with the traditional population showing broader genetic mobilization in response to organic P.
population_specificity: Maize (Zea mays L.) seedlings, specifically a traditional Italian population (VA572) and a modern commercial hybrid (P1547).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a microalgae-based method for selectively recovering phosphorus from high-fluoride-phosphoric wastewater.
results_summary: Chlorella sp. effectively reduced phosphorus levels in wastewater from 12.76 mg/L to 5.00 mg/L over 16 days, outperforming other microalgae species. Phosphorus reduction occurred through cellular uptake and absorption by functional groups on extracellular polymeric substances (EPS).
population_specificity: High-fluoride-phosphoric wastewater

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of phosphorus (via phosphate addition) on enhancing mineralization during algae-bacteria co-growth in the treatment of oil sands process-affected water (OSPW).
results_summary: Phosphate addition (biostimulation) promoted photosynthetic biomass growth but exacerbated oligotrophic conditions and prolonged organic production phases, reducing mineralization rates and posing potential eutrophication risks. Controlled light exposure with biological treatments was identified as a scalable, energy-efficient solution for complex wastewater challenges.
population_specificity: Synthetic oil sands process-affected water (OSPW) under laboratory conditions.
study_duration: Photocatalytic pre-treatments lasted 24 hours or longer, followed by biological treatment in illuminated microcosms (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how steam and phosphorus modifications to ZSM-5 zeolite affect ethylene oligomerization for liquid fuel production.
results_summary: Steam treatment created mesopores (2-3 nm and 10-20 nm), while phosphorus aggregation blocked channels. The steam-modified sample (HZ-700) achieved a 78.1% yield of liquid fuels, a 40% increase over the unmodified sample, with improved stability due to mesopore-enhanced diffusion.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on catalyst material, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficiency and mechanisms of simultaneous nitrogen and phosphorus removal by the bacterial strain Paracoccus versutus under aerobic conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Paracoccus versutus (strain JUST-3) effectively removed nitrogen and phosphorus under optimized conditions (C/N ratio of 10, P/N ratio of 0.2, 35°C, pH 8.0), with exogenous signal molecules enhancing its performance. The research also identified novel regulatory mechanisms in microbial quorum-sensing systems.
population_specificity: Bacterial strain (Paracoccus versutus) in a controlled laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human consumption; optimized conditions for bacterial performance included sodium acetate as carbon source, C/N ratio of 10, P/N ratio of 0.2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of modified biochar and metal salts (kieserite and CaCl2) in enhancing phosphorus recovery from biogas digestate.
results_summary: Modified biochar increased phosphorus recovery to 52%, while metal salts achieved 65%, compared to 35% in the control. The study also found that metal ions promoted the formation of non-labile phosphorus, reducing nutrient runoff and improving long-term nutrient availability.
population_specificity: Laboratory setting (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Varying concentrations and treatment times (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated MSA2O biofilm reactor and HVCWs system for phosphorus and nitrogen removal in rural wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The system achieved high removal efficiencies for phosphorus (86.3%) and nitrogen (90.6%), consistently meeting stringent effluent standards. Microbial analysis revealed key functional bacteria contributing to phosphorus uptake and nutrient removal.
population_specificity: Rural wastewater in northern China.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (system parameters: HRT 21-32 h, aeration rate 4.0 m³/h, carbon source dosing 1.25 L/h, PAC dosing 0.55 L/h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolism of higher-order volatile fatty acids (VFAs) in fermentation-enhanced enhanced biological phosphorus removal (F-EBPR) systems to better understand the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that butyrate uptake in F-EBPR systems leads to the formation of both typical and atypical polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) through β-oxidation and condensation pathways. Metagenomic analysis identified genes for higher-order VFA metabolism in polyphosphate accumulating organisms (PAOs) and glycogen accumulating organisms (GAOs), highlighting limitations in current F-EBPR models.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment systems (microbial communities involved in phosphorus removal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of cattle grazing and mowing on the spatial and vertical distribution of water-extractable phosphorus (WEP) in riparian areas to understand potential phosphorus loss during snowmelt.
results_summary: The study found that high-density grazing and mowing significantly reduced biomass WEP, particularly in lower riparian locations, but did not affect other WEP sources. The Ah soil horizon was the largest WEP pool, while biomass contributed 25% of the total WEP.
population_specificity: Riparian areas in agricultural watersheds, specifically focusing on cold climates.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study examined grazing and mowing treatments, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low phosphorus (P) levels on foxtail millet growth and yield-related traits, focusing on genotypic variation and P dilution's role in yield determination.
results_summary: The study found significant genotypic variation in foxtail millet under low-P conditions, with tiller number being a key indicator of growth potential. Grain yield under low-P conditions was strongly influenced by genetic yield potential under high-P conditions, and P dilution played a more critical role than total P concentration in determining yield.
population_specificity: Foxtail millet genotypes (n=10) from the ICRISAT Genebank core collection, grown in regions with low-P soils (e.g., Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia).
effective_dosage: Low-P conditions (<5 ppm, measured via Hedley Fractionation Method).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of biochar as an adsorbent for phosphorus recovery from wastewater and explore practical applications for the adsorbed phosphorus.
results_summary: The study found that biochar is effective in adsorbing phosphorus from wastewater, with potential for simultaneous removal of other contaminants. It also highlighted practical uses for phosphorus-laden biochar, such as slow-release fertilizers and heavy metal adsorbents.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on wastewater treatment and phosphorus recovery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the degradability, photothermal performance, and therapeutic efficacy of biodegradable ferrous sulfide nanosheets (FeS NS) against traditional black phosphorus nanosheets (BP NS) for tumor theranostic applications.
results_summary: FeS NS demonstrated superior degradability and enhanced photothermal performance compared to BP NS, leading to improved photothermal therapy (PTT) efficacy. FeS NS also released H2S and Fe2+, which inhibited mitochondrial respiration, triggered ferroptosis, and provided MRI-guided tumor therapy.
population_specificity: Tumor cells in an acidic microenvironment (in vitro/in vivo study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a robust 2D biomimetic nanoplatform using Cu2+-modified black phosphorus nanosheets (BP@Cu2+) to enhance the targeted delivery and controlled release of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin (DOX).
results_summary: The study found that the BP@Cu2+/DOX-CMs nanoplatform significantly enhanced DOX loading capacity, minimized premature release in serum, and enabled controlled release in the acidic tumor microenvironment. Combined with near-infrared laser irradiation, it achieved synergistic multimodal therapy, integrating phototherapy, chemotherapy, chemodynamic therapy, and cuproptosis to enhance antitumor efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied by the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functionalized magnetically separated electric arc furnace dust (ms-EAFD) in recovering phosphorus and removing extracellular DNA (exDNA) from wastewater.
results_summary: Functionalized ms-EAFD significantly improved phosphate removal efficiency (from 7.1% to over 70%) and adsorption capacity (from 0.5 to above 4.5 mg/g). It also demonstrated high exDNA removal efficiency (75-100%) in low-phosphate wastewater, though efficiency dropped to ~20% in high-phosphate conditions.
population_specificity: Municipal wastewater treatment plant effluent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance phosphorus availability in sewage sludge biochar through potassium doping and assess its effectiveness as a circular economy material for plant uptake.
results_summary: Potassium acetate doping tripled water-extractable phosphorus in 500°C biochar, improving wheat stem biomass by 28% and grain phosphorus uptake by 29%. Wood ash extract doubled phosphorus availability compared to untreated biochar.
population_specificity: Wheat plants in a pot trial.
effective_dosage: Not specified (doping with potassium acetate, wood ash, or its water extract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the predictive performance and physical interpretability of a hybrid ODE model for biological phosphorus removal in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The modified SH-ODE achieved high predictive performance (R² = 0.93) for phosphate dynamics and improved physical interpretability by embedding stoichiometric constraints and automatic calibration. Supporting data further enhanced phosphate estimation through biomass compensation.
population_specificity: Anaerobic/aerobic sequencing batch reactors (wastewater treatment systems).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary phosphorus intake influences cardiovascular mortality in asthma patients.
results_summary: Higher dietary phosphorus intake was associated with reduced cardiovascular mortality, with a non-linear dose-response relationship and a protective threshold at 1,861.52 mg/day. The effect diminished above this threshold.
population_specificity: 7,539 asthma patients from the NHANES 1999-2018 cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel, eco-friendly synthesis of Cu3P particles on yeast-derived biochar for catalytic wastewater treatment, focusing on RhB degradation efficiency and stability.
results_summary: Cu3P/BC significantly enhanced RhB degradation (25.2-fold increase in removal efficiency) and chemical oxygen demand removal (4-fold increase), maintained robust performance across real water matrices (70.7–88.6% efficiency), and showed stability over four cycles with minimal copper leaching (≤0.51 mg/L). Reactive oxygen species (•OH, O2•-, 1O2) played critical roles in degradation via Cu(II)/Cu(I) redox cycling.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro and real water matrix testing).
effective_dosage: Not specified (precursor: Cu2+; phosphorus source: mannan-phosphate from yeast cell walls).
study_duration: Not specified (four cycles tested for stability).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve phosphorus bioavailability from poultry litter ash for fertilizer use through microwave-assisted thermochemical treatment.
results_summary: Microwave treatment increased phosphorus solubility by forming NaCaPO4 crystals, enhancing plant uptake potential, though higher amorphous content reduced solubility. The process also yielded glass materials with promising optical properties.
population_specificity: Poultry litter ash from laying hens' manure incineration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel green biomass-based MgO material (PS-MgO) for phosphorus recovery from wastewater and its potential integration with advanced oxidation technologies.
results_summary: PS-MgO demonstrated superior phosphorus adsorption capacity (429.4 mg/g) compared to commercial MgO materials, maintained high performance across a wide pH range, and showed potential for reuse as a fertilizer. Combining MgO adsorption with dielectric barrier discharge plasma technology enhanced phosphorus recovery from livestock wastewater by 1.4-1.7 times.
population_specificity: Wastewater (specifically livestock wastewater)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short-term impact of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) on denitrifying phosphorus removal systems in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: PFOA initially enhanced phosphate removal via the anaerobic phosphorus release pathway but later inhibited it in the second cycle. Nitrogen removal was unaffected, while COD removal efficiency correlated with specific HSL concentrations. Increased PFOA concentrations led to higher ROS levels, enzyme activity, and looser sludge structure.
population_specificity: Denitrifying phosphorus removal systems (laboratory batch experiments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous VOCs (syringic acid and 1-butene) influence root responses, phosphorus acquisition, and stress resilience in Cunninghamia lanceolata under phosphorus limitation.
results_summary: 1-butene significantly improved root morphology, phosphorus acquisition, and stress resilience compared to syringic acid, enhancing underground phosphorus use efficiency by 25.6% and increasing antioxidant enzyme activity. Proteomic analysis revealed 1-butene's role in altering stress response and phosphate transport proteins.
population_specificity: Clonal Chinese fir seedlings (Cunninghamia lanceolata).
effective_dosage: 1.0 mM KH2PO4 (phosphorus supply) and 0 mM KH2PO4 (no phosphorus supply).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the process model of sidestream EBPR (S2EBPR) by better understanding the roles of glycogen-accumulating organisms (GAO) and phosphorus-accumulating organisms (PAO) in nutrient removal.
results_summary: The study found that modifying anaerobic hydrolysis, GAO glycogen storage, and ORP activity improved model predictions by 5% for nitrate/nitrite and 10-60% for phosphorus. It also identified denitrifying GAO as potentially more active in nitric oxide reduction than denitrifying PAO.
population_specificity: Full-scale S2EBPR demonstration at the Calumet Water Reclamation Plant (wastewater treatment context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the synergistic effects of Mo cation doping and P anion doping on the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance of a Co-Fe hydroxide catalyst.
results_summary: The study found that P doping induced the formation of an amorphous surface layer of hypophosphite Fe(PO3)3, which enhanced OER performance by lowering overpotential and improving kinetics. The Fe/F-MoCo-POx catalyst exhibited high durability and efficiency at high current densities.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on catalyst materials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess trends in total phosphorus (TP) discharge from the Everglades Agricultural Area (EAA) farms and identify TP hot spots to inform targeted interventions.
results_summary: TP discharge from EAA farms averaged 74.68 ± 38.87 µg/L, with spatial and temporal variations observed. A decreasing trend in TP concentration was noted from 2000-2012, but an increasing trend occurred from 2010-2019, with 31% of farms posing above-average pollution risk.
population_specificity: Farms in the Everglades Agricultural Area (EAA) in South Florida, USA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a multifunctional nanocarrier using nano-sized black phosphorus (NBP) for targeted chemo-photothermal therapy in breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The nanocarrier demonstrated high loading efficiency of the anti-tumor agent I3C, targeted delivery to breast tumors, superior photothermal conversion, and significant inhibition of tumor growth through combined chemo-photothermal therapy.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (specific human population not specified, likely preclinical model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal combination of nitrogen and phosphorus fertilizers to enhance alfalfa growth, yield, and economic returns while mitigating soil pollution.
results_summary: The study found that nitrogen and phosphorus application significantly increased alfalfa dry matter yield, plant height, stem thickness, crude protein, and ether extract, while reducing neutral and acid detergent fiber. The optimal treatment (286.3 kg·ha-1 urea + 192 kg·ha-1 monoammonium phosphate) increased net profit by 44.18% compared to no-fertilizer treatment.
population_specificity: Alfalfa (Medicago Sativa L.) grown in alkaline desert soils of northern Xinjiang, China.
effective_dosage: 192 kg·ha-1 monoammonium phosphate (combined with 286.3 kg·ha-1 urea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early shading treatments affect the drought tolerance of Pinus yunnanensis seedlings, focusing on phosphorus utilization efficiency and carbon-nitrogen-phosphorus balance.
results_summary: Early shading influenced phosphorus utilization efficiency and carbon consumption under drought stress, with seedlings under 0% (HL) and 80% (LL) shading showing better drought resistance than those under 55% (ML) shading.
population_specificity: Pinus yunnanensis seedlings
study_duration: 90 days of shading followed by 30 days of drought stress

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop sulfur-phosphorus co-doped porous carbon adsorbents from glycerol and elemental sulfur for CO2 capture.
results_summary: The best adsorbent (P‑carbon-2000mgS-H2O2) demonstrated high CO2 adsorption capacity (1.95 mmol/g at 25°C) and selectivity over N2, with physical adsorption mechanisms dominating. The study suggests this method effectively utilizes glycerol and sulfur for large-scale CO2 capture applications.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a microneedle system loaded with black phosphorus nanosheets encapsulating baicalin for treating androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The BP-BA@MNs system demonstrated efficient photothermal conversion, controlled drug release, enhanced cellular uptake, and significant modulation of gene expression in dermal papilla cells, leading to improved efficacy against AGA in vivo with good biocompatibility and biosafety.
population_specificity: Human dermal papilla cells treated with dihydrotestosterone and testosterone-induced AGA in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a repeatedly oxygen-rich anode environment in microbial fuel cells could enhance the enrichment of functional bacteria (EHB and DPAOs) for improved nitrogen and phosphorus removal from household wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that repeated oxygen-rich conditions enhanced the growth of functional bacteria, achieving up to 55% total phosphorus removal, alongside significant nitrogen removal. Up-regulation of genes related to phosphate metabolism and pollutant removal was observed.
population_specificity: Household wastewater (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test innovative encapsulated phosphorus fertilizers to prevent nutrient leaching and improve plant growth.
results_summary: The study found that the encapsulated fertilizers showed slow-release behavior and promoted the growth of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings, with one formulation demonstrating enhanced growth promotion likely due to the synergistic effect of phosphorus and modified chitosan.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how micro-/nanobubble oxygenation irrigation affects soil phosphorus availability and maize yield by examining enzyme activity, microbial communities, and soil phosphorus dynamics.
results_summary: The study found that micro-/nanobubble oxygenation irrigation significantly increased available phosphorus content (21.3%) and alkaline phosphatase activity (15.4%) in maize rhizosphere soil, altered bacterial community structure, and enhanced fungal network complexity, ultimately improving phosphorus availability.
population_specificity: Rhizosphere soil of maize (agricultural context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize phosphorus removal from pulp mill effluents using cobalt ferrite nanoparticles to address variability in phosphorus concentrations and minimize environmental impact.
results_summary: The study identified optimal conditions for over 90% phosphorus removal, including specific sorbent doses and pH ranges, with cobalt ferrite nanoparticles proving highly effective. This approach offers a sustainable strategy for phosphorus recovery and water quality maintenance.
population_specificity: Pulp mill effluents, specifically from Eucalyptus bleached kraft pulp mills.
effective_dosage: Sorbent doses greater than 1.3 g/L (15 min contact time), 0.97 g/L (1 h), and 0.83 g/L (24 h).
study_duration: Contact times of 15 min, 1 h, and 24 h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of black phosphorus nanosheets (BPNSs) combined with doxorubicin (DOX) and targeted to hepatic stellate cells (aHSCs) for treating liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The BP/DOX@RMV-VA nanovesicles demonstrated excellent biosafety, effective targeting of aHSCs, strong antiproliferative effects, and reversal of fibrotic phenotypes in both cultured cells and CCl4-injured mice, significantly improving liver structure and function without detectable cardiotoxicity.
population_specificity: Activated hepatic stellate cells (aHSCs) in vitro and CCl4-injured mice in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial ability and biocompatibility of black phosphorus nanosheets (BPs) decorated with melittin (Mel) and their potential to accelerate wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that nanocomposites made from middle-sized BPs (BPs/Mel-7) exhibited strong antibacterial ability and good biocompatibility, and they accelerated skin wound healing infected by Staphylococcus aureus.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cadmium (Cd) exposure affects phosphorus (Pi) metabolism and whether chokeberry extract (AME) can mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Cd exposure disrupted Pi homeostasis, lowering serum levels and increasing urinary loss, while AME improved Pi regulation by normalizing calciotropic hormones and Klotho levels.
population_specificity: Female rats
effective_dosage: Cd at 1 and 5 mg/kg diet; AME at 0.1%

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black phosphorus quantum dots (BPQDs) could safely and efficiently remove atherosclerotic plaques in a high-fat diet mouse model.
results_summary: BPQDs administered intravenously every other day for 3 weeks cleared 45.3% of atherosclerotic plaques, outperforming traditional statins, suggesting potential for clinical use without dietary changes.
population_specificity: High-fat diet ApoE-/- model mice
effective_dosage: Every other day intravenous administration (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid and reliable method for detecting soil-available phosphorus to address inadequacies in traditional large-scale soil assessment methods in China.
results_summary: The proposed method demonstrated conformity with the national standard, showing a relative standard deviation of less than 3%. The non-contact conductivity detector and neural network model improved field operations and data analysis efficiency.
population_specificity: Soil samples from Liaoning brown soil, Henan yellow tidal soil, Heilongjiang black soil, and Anhui tidal soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and quantify major phosphorus sources in the Xijiang Estuary, China, focusing on aquaculture effluent's role in phosphorus pollution.
results_summary: The study found that aquaculture effluent was the largest contributor to phosphorus loading (30.5%), surpassing other sources like livestock feces (29.6%), WWTPs effluent (24.0%), and agricultural soil (15.8%). Significant spatial differences in phosphorus source contributions were also observed.
population_specificity: Aquatic ecosystems in the Xijiang Estuary, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biocompatible, controlled, and stable carrier system using black phosphorus nanosheets integrated with niosomes for chemo-phototherapy of cancers.
results_summary: The NBID system demonstrated high drug loading efficiency (>90%), controlled release of drugs in a pH- and light-responsive manner, and induced DNA damage, photothermal, and photodynamic effects, significantly enhancing tumor eradication in 2D and 3D cancer models.
population_specificity: In vitro cancer cell models (2D cell culture and 3D tumor spheroids).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the phosphorus-solubilizing mechanisms of the fungal strain *Trametes gibbosa* T-41 and compare its effectiveness with organic and inorganic phosphorus sources.
results_summary: The study found that *T. gibbosa* T-41 exhibited higher phosphorus solubilization capacity with organic phosphorus (calcium phytin) compared to inorganic phosphorus (tricalcium phosphate), accompanied by increased enzyme activity and organic acid production. Transcriptomic and metabolomic analyses revealed altered metabolic pathways and key metabolites influencing phosphorus solubilization.
population_specificity: Soil-derived fungal strain (*Trametes gibbosa* T-41).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-salt diet (HSD) impacts phosphorus (Pi) metabolism in mice, given its known disruption of calcium metabolism and suspected link between sodium and phosphorus pathways.
results_summary: HSD increased urinary Pi excretion, decreased fecal Pi excretion, and altered hormonal levels (elevated parathyroid hormone, reduced fibroblast growth factor 23). Intestinal Pi transporter expression (Npt2b and NHE3) was upregulated, suggesting enhanced intestinal Pi absorption.
population_specificity: Male C57 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how long-term brackish drip irrigation affects soil phosphorus transformation, microbial diversity, and functional gene expression in cotton fields.
results_summary: Long-term brackish drip irrigation reduced cotton dry matter weight, phosphorus uptake, and yield but increased soil phosphorus content and altered microbial communities and functional gene expression related to phosphorus cycling.
population_specificity: Cotton fields under brackish and freshwater drip irrigation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (irrigation water salinity: 0.35 dS·m-1 for freshwater, 8.04 dS·m-1 for brackish water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological properties of black phosphorus nanosheets (BPNSs) and explore their potential applications for treating peri-implantitis.
results_summary: The study found that BPNSs exhibit unique osteogenic, antibacterial, and antioxidant properties, along with promoting angiogenesis and nerve regeneration, making them a promising candidate for treating infection-related bone defects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the ability of Klebsormidium sp. microalgae to remove phosphorus from high-phosphorus wastewater and investigate factors influencing its absorption.
results_summary: Klebsormidium sp. achieved over 90% phosphorus removal in high-concentration wastewater (>20 mgP/L), with 50-80% of absorbed phosphorus entering intracellular polymers. Nitrogen concentration and light-to-dark ratio significantly influenced phosphorus storage, while phosphorus concentration and light intensity did not.
population_specificity: High-phosphorus wastewater (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study varied nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations and light conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of enhanced biological phosphorus removal (EBPR) and recovery technologies for reducing dependency on nonrenewable phosphorus reserves.
results_summary: The study found that EBPR offers advantages over chemical precipitation methods, including reduced chemical use, lower sludge volumes, and improved phosphorus recovery quality, though comprehensive assessment of recovery potential from target streams remains unexplored.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment plants and phosphorus recovery systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of black phosphorus nanosheets (BPNS) in repairing infectious bone defects by evaluating their antibacterial, osteogenic, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: BPNS demonstrated exceptional biocompatibility, bioactivity, and antibacterial effects, including intrinsic properties, photothermal therapy, photodynamic therapy, and drug delivery. The study highlighted BPNS-based composite biomaterials as promising solutions for infectious bone defect repair.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on biomaterial applications in bone tissue engineering).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) fertilization proportions to enhance the growth and nutrient-use efficiency of Pinus yunnanensis seedlings.
results_summary: The study found that NP proportioning significantly improved seedling growth, biomass accumulation, and nutrient utilization, with T5 (N 0.4 g·per-1 and P 3 g·per-1) showing superior performance. Transcriptomic analysis revealed upregulated genes related to nutrient uptake, cell division, and photosynthesis, correlating with enhanced growth.
population_specificity: Pinus yunnanensis seedlings in an open nursery setting.
effective_dosage: Optimal fertilization dosage was N 0.32–0.58 g·per-1 and P 3.02–4.95 g·per-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how phosphorus (P) and nitrogen (N) additions influence non-structural carbohydrates (NSCs) and their components in Pinus yunnanensis after coppicing.
results_summary: Phosphorus treatment significantly increased NSC levels in sprouts and starch content in stems and sprouts. Combined N and P application further improved soluble sugar content in stems, with the highest NSC concentration observed in roots, stems, and sprouts under the D4 treatment (N 0.6 g/plant + P 2.0 g/plant).
population_specificity: Pinus yunnanensis Franch. (a plant species)
effective_dosage: P0 (0 g/plant), P (2 g/plant), P+ (4 g/plant); N0 (0 g/plant), N+ (0.6 g/plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel hydrogel microsphere-immobilized Bacillus velezensis system for integrated degradation of pollutants, including total phosphorus (TP), in food wastewater.
results_summary: The system achieved a 36.84% degradation rate for total phosphorus (TP) in food wastewater and remained highly efficient after five reuses, demonstrating its potential for phosphorus removal.
population_specificity: Food wastewater (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/L nano-TiO2 in the preformed gel solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the migration and retention of phosphorus during thermal conversion of sewage sludge under varying temperatures and atmospheric conditions to optimize phosphorus recovery.
results_summary: Below 700°C, phosphorus was largely retained in sewage sludge char/ash, with minimal atmospheric influence. At higher temperatures (700-900°C), nitrogen atmosphere reduced phosphorus retention (86.1% to 60.2%), while oxygen and steam improved retention (70.5% and 76.2%, respectively). Steam notably enhanced conversion of non-apatite phosphorus to apatite phosphorus, improving bioavailability.
population_specificity: Sewage sludge subjected to thermal conversion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial efficacy and safety of black phosphorus (BP) loaded with strontium ions (Sr2+) as a photothermal agent for treating bacterial infections.
results_summary: BP-Sr demonstrated strong antibacterial effects, killing 99% of bacteria within 10 minutes under laser irradiation, while showing no significant cytotoxicity at concentrations ≤50 μg/mL. The study also found that bacterial death was linked to membrane destruction, metabolic disorders, and transport damage, with inflammation significantly reduced after treatment.
population_specificity: Bacterial infections (in vitro study, no human subjects specified).
study_duration: Not specified (acute effects measured after 10 min of laser treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how fertilizer placement, source, and cover crop management affect phosphorus speciation in soil and runoff sediments in a no-till corn-soybean cropping system.
results_summary: The study found that management practices influenced exchangeable, organic matter-associated, and Fe-bound phosphorus fractions in sediments and exchangeable/residual fractions in soil. Cover crops depleted Fe-associated phosphorus in soil and sediment, potentially altering phosphorus bioavailability in aquatic ecosystems.
population_specificity: No-till corn-soybean cropping system with winter cover crops (wheat, rapeseed, hairy vetch, triticale, cereal rye).
effective_dosage: Fall broadcast diammonium phosphate and spring subsurface injected ammonium polyphosphate (specific amounts not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aluminum (Al) affects iron (Fe) homeostasis in rice and whether this occurs indirectly by inducing phosphorus (P) deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that Al alleviated Fe deficiency-induced chlorosis in rice, decreased expression of Fe deficiency marker genes, and partially recovered photosynthesis. Al also induced expression of a P deficiency marker gene, and excess P reversed Al's effects on chlorosis, suggesting Al indirectly induces P deficiency.
population_specificity: Rice plants (Oryza sativa L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how phosphorus (P) starvation affects stem growth and P distribution in poplar trees, and the role of PagSND1-B1 in regulating P absorption and xylem development.
results_summary: The study found that P starvation severely reduces P in stems, inhibiting wood formation, but overexpression of PagSND1-B1 enhances P starvation resistance and xylem development by regulating the phosphorus transporter PagPHT1;5a, leading to increased P accumulation in stems.
population_specificity: Poplar trees (woody model species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of combining aluminum sulfate (ALS) with high molecular weight organic polymers for phosphorus removal from domestic wastewater and its potential for reuse.
results_summary: The combination achieved 95-99% removal of particles, turbidity, and phosphates, reduced ALS usage by 40%, and improved phosphorus bioavailability in sludge for fertilizer use. Enhanced removal mechanisms were linked to polymer charge density, zeta potential changes, and optimized dosing processes.
population_specificity: Domestic wastewater treatment (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on process optimization rather than fixed dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of end-of-pipe filters containing activated alumina and iron filings in reducing dissolved phosphorus concentrations in bioretention system effluent.
results_summary: The filters reduced dissolved reactive phosphorus concentrations by an average of 37-29% initially, improving to 49-39% after several months, and also reduced total phosphorus by 29-24%. The study demonstrated a practical solution to mitigate phosphorus pollution from green stormwater infrastructure.
population_specificity: Bioretention systems in Milwaukee, WI (environmental study, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether biochar-immobilized Bacillus megaterium (BMB) combined with organic fertilizer (MOF treatment) could enhance phosphorus availability in soil and improve phosphorus uptake in rice plants.
results_summary: The MOF treatment significantly increased soil available phosphorus (7.83 mg kg-1), bioavailable P reservoirs (H2O-Pi and NaHCO3-Pi), and rice plant phosphorus content (0.469% in shoots, 0.516% in roots) while promoting root development. The treatment also enhanced carbon source utilization (carbohydrates, polymers, amino acids) and altered microbial community dynamics (increased pqqC, decreased phoD).
population_specificity: Rice plants in controlled pot experiments.
effective_dosage: Not specified (abstract does not detail exact dosage of BMB or organic fertilizer).
study_duration: At least 38 days (measurement of soil AP at this time point).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a dual management approach using phosphorus-solubilizing rhizobacteria (PS-RB) to enhance plant growth by improving soil fertility and reducing pathogenic stress.
results_summary: The study found that selected PS-RB strains significantly improved maize plant growth parameters, including root length, shoot length, chlorophyll content, and nutrient uptake under pathogenic stress. Specific strains like PSB-25 and PSB-16 showed notable enhancements in root length and enzymatic activity, while field trials indicated the effectiveness of combining PS-RB with recommended fertilizer doses.
population_specificity: Maize plants under pathogenic stress from Colletotrichum chlorophyti and Xanthomonas axonopodis.
effective_dosage: 100% RDF (Recommended Dose of Fertilizer) + PSB16 (specific strain dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate progress in biologically mediated adsorption and precipitation of phosphorus (P) from waste streams for environmental and agricultural applications.
results_summary: The study found that industry wastes like steel slags and hydrotalcite show high P retention capacities, while biomineral struvite formation offers adaptable P removal and recovery for wastewater treatment, supporting nutrient recycling and food production.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on waste streams and wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of polyethylene glycol-functionalized black phosphorus (BP-PEG) nanosheets in breast cancer models.
results_summary: BP-PEG significantly inhibited tumor growth and metastasis by reshaping the tumor immune microenvironment, primarily through neutrophil recruitment and activation, without directly inducing cytotoxicity in tumor cells. It also enhanced the antitumor activity of neutrophils and natural killer (NK) cells.
population_specificity: Immunocompetent mouse models (4T1 orthotopic BALB/c mice and MMTV-PyMT transgenic mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different phosphorus-solubilizing fungi and their combinations on the growth, photosynthesis, and biochemical characteristics of F. taipaiensis P. Y. Li to identify optimal strains for artificial cultivation.
results_summary: The study found that phosphorus-solubilizing fungi significantly improved plant growth indices (e.g., leaf area, plant height, stem diameter), photosynthetic parameters, and antioxidant activity, with the S5 group (A. tubingensis and A. niger) showing the best overall effects. Some combinations (e.g., S7) exhibited antagonistic effects, reducing certain biochemical indicators.
population_specificity: F. taipaiensis P. Y. Li plants cultivated in indoor pots.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fungal inoculation details provided but no quantitative dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a wastewater treatment plant upgrade on phosphorus levels and nutrient conditions in nearshore Lake Ontario.
results_summary: The study found that total phosphorus (TP) in effluent changed only slightly after the upgrade, with no obvious improvement in nearshore TP concentrations or phosphorus tissue content of Cladophora. The upgrade increased nitrite+nitrate (NO2+3) inputs, suggesting trade-offs in nutrient management.
population_specificity: Nearshore regions of Lake Ontario, specifically around the Duffin Creek Water Pollution Control Plant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how foliar traits and tree growth in northern hardwood species respond to nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) fertilization, including potential co-limitation effects.
results_summary: Phosphorus addition shifted foliar traits toward an "acquisitive" spectrum, suggesting improved nutrient-use efficiency. Some species showed lower foliar P under N addition and lower foliar N under P addition, indicating N and P co-limitation. Community-level responses also reflected co-limitation.
population_specificity: Six northern hardwood tree species (Acer rubrum, Acer saccharum, Betula alleghaniensis, Betula papyrifera, Fagus grandifolia, Prunus pensylvanica) across 10 mid- and late-successional forest stands in New Hampshire, USA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how intercropping rice and soybean under dry cultivation affects phosphorus uptake and crop growth, focusing on the roles of root morphology and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) colonization.
results_summary: Intercropping rice and soybean increased total biomass and yield compared to monoculture, with soybean benefiting from root morphological adjustments and rice relying more on AMF colonization for phosphorus uptake.
population_specificity: Dry-cultivated rice (Oryza sativa L.) and soybean (Glycine max L. Merr.) in field and pot experiments.
effective_dosage: Two phosphorus levels (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and methods of oral supplementation of phosphate ions through extemporaneous preparations tailored to individual patient needs.
results_summary: The study provided an overview of commonly used extemporaneous phosphate formulations, detailing the amounts of ions in mass and molar terms, but did not report specific clinical outcomes or efficacy data.
population_specificity: Patients requiring ion supplementation at the University Hospital in Motol (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (formulas tailored to individual needs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of nitrogen and phosphorus on yield, nutrient use efficiency, and growth parameters of sorghum in saline soils.
results_summary: Phosphorus application improved sorghum yield, biomass, nutrient accumulation, and other growth parameters, with the best performance observed at 60 P2O5 kg ha-1 combined with 180 N kg ha-1. However, nutrient use efficiency decreased with higher phosphorus and nitrogen application.
population_specificity: Sorghum plants grown in saline soils.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF23) as an early marker for metabolic bone disease of prematurity (MBDP) in at-risk premature newborns, compared to traditional markers like phosphorus and alkaline phosphatase.
results_summary: The study found that FGF23 levels at 3-4 weeks of life could identify MBDP earlier than traditional markers (phosphorus and ALP), allowing for timely nutritional intervention. Low FGF23 levels indicated the need for treatment adjustments even when phosphorus and ALP levels were normal.
population_specificity: Preterm newborns (gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1500 g) at risk for MBDP.
study_duration: Measurements taken at 3-4 weeks of life, with follow-up as needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), hypophosphataemia, and elevated fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) levels, and the effects of phosphorus supplementation in this context.
results_summary: The study found that phosphorus supplementation, alongside other treatments, improved TmP/GFR and reduced FGF23 levels in an 11-year-old SLE patient with hypophosphataemia. Bone turnover markers were also affected, suggesting changes in bone metabolism due to FGF23 dysregulation.
population_specificity: 11-year-old girl with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and hypophosphataemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin D3 supplementation on serum phosphorus levels and bone health in exclusively breastfed infants.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D3 supplementation at 400 IU/d significantly increased serum 25(OH)D and phosphorus levels in infants by 4 months of age, but did not affect bone mineralization. Severe vitamin D deficiency was associated with higher parathyroid hormone levels and lower bone mineral content.
population_specificity: Exclusively breastfed newborns and their mothers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of taurine supplementation on aerobic and anaerobic performance, metabolic stress, muscle soreness, and recovery.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some improvements in VO2 max and recovery, but limited and varied findings prevent definitive conclusions on taurine's efficacy. The timing of ingestion and type of exercise protocol may influence its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Athletes (participants under 50 years old without health issues)
effective_dosage: 1g - 6g, either acute (10-15 min to 2h prior to exercise) or chronic (7 days - 8 weeks)
study_duration: Ranged from acute doses to 8 weeks
